title: The hard right and left policies more popular with the public than people realise
text:

With Brexit, the re-election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the Labour party , the rise of UKIP and even Donald Trump being President-elect of the US, a new wave of radical politics has washed over the world in 2016. 
Yet while political experts have scratched their heads as to what has caused it, the obvious answer is they are reflecting the public mood. 
For opinion polls published even before these seismic political happenings showed that the public is still in many ways more radical than the politicians who are supposed to represent them. 
And this applies to policies seen as hard left and hard right. 
For a start, re-nationalising the railways. There has been growing talk of this of late with the ongoing chaos on Southern Rail. 
However underfire Transport Secretary Chris Grayling has dismissed it out of hand. Commuters stage a protest at Victoria Station, London (Photo: PA) 
Yet an opinion poll by YouGov revealed 59% support for it against 21% who oppose it. And Tory supporters also backed it by 48% to 35%. 
Despite this, political expert Dr Martin Farr from Newcastle University thinks it has still some way to go before it becomes policy for Labour. 
“Once it does, the Tories and all the private rail companies will launch their campaign against it. 
“It would be costly and complicated for a start and once you start talking about this, will the public still back it?” 
Another left wing policy which has proved popular is upping the National Living Wage to £10 an hour. The public back such an increase by 61% to 19%. 
And while there is always much scoffing at suggestions by the left of increasing the tax rate for high earners as more a reflection of wealth envy than political reality, this too has considerable public support. 
A poll which asked people if they would back a 60p rate for those who earned over £150,000 had 52% backing against 23% who opposed it. 
Dr Farr said: “It sounds great and who, for a start, wouldn’t want the less well off to get more money. 
“But again the financial reality could see higher income tax rates to afford it, businesses would struggle to cope, the people who Labour need to attract. 
“In theory these policies seem fine but they are easily unpicked.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
